paragraphs.original: [12]If you're experienced at negotiations, you already know how to ask such questions. [13] If you're not, there's a trick you can use in this situation. Investors know you're inexperienced at raising money.
paragraphs.translated: [12]如果你在谈判方面有经验，你已经知道如何提出这样的问题。[13]如果你没有经验，这里有一个技巧可以使用。投资者知道你在筹集资金方面缺乏经验。

paragraphs.original: Inexperience there doesn't make you unattractive. Being a noob at technology would, if you're starting a technology startup, but not being a noob at fundraising. Larry and Sergey were noobs at fundraising.
paragraphs.translated: 缺乏经验并不会让你失去吸引力。如果你要创办一家科技初创公司，对技术一窍不通确实会是个问题，但对融资不熟悉却不是。拉里和谢尔盖在融资方面就是新手。

paragraphs.original: So you can just confess that you're inexperienced at this and ask how their process works and where you are in it. [14] Get the first commitment.The biggest factor in most investors' opinions of you is the opinion of other investors.
paragraphs.translated: 所以你可以坦诚自己在这方面没有经验，并询问他们的流程以及你现在所处的阶段。[14] 获得首次承诺。大多数投资者对你的看法主要受其他投资者意见的影响。

paragraphs.original: Once you start getting investors to commit, it becomes increasingly easy to get more to. But the other side of this coin is that it's often hard to get the first commitment.Getting the first substantial offer can be half the total difficulty of fundraising.
paragraphs.translated: 一旦你开始让投资者承诺投资，吸引更多的投资者就会变得越来越容易。但另一方面，获得第一个承诺往往非常困难。获得第一个重要的投资承诺可能是整个融资过程中最困难的一半。

paragraphs.original: What counts as a substantial offer depends on who it's from and how much it is. Money from friends and family doesn't usually count, no matter how much. But if you get $50k from a well known VC firm or angel investor, that will usually be enough to set things rolling.
paragraphs.translated: 被视为重大投资的额度取决于资金来源和金额大小。来自亲朋好友的资金通常不计入，无论金额多少。但如果你从知名的风险投资公司或天使投资者那里获得50万美元，这通常足以启动项目。

paragraphs.original: [15] Close committed money.It's not a deal till the money's in the bank. I often hear inexperienced founders say things like "We've raised $800,000," only to discover that zero of it is in the bank so far.
paragraphs.translated: [15] 确保资金到位。资金未到账前，交易就不能算达成。我经常听到没有经验的创始人说“我们已经筹集了80万美元”，结果却发现迄今为止一分钱都没到账。

paragraphs.original: Remember the twin fears that torment investors? The fear of missing out that makes them jump early, and the fear of jumping onto a turd that results? This is a market where people are exceptionally prone to buyer's remorse.
paragraphs.translated: 还记得让投资者困扰的两种恐惧吗？一种是害怕错过良机，让他们过早地采取行动；另一种是害怕跳进陷阱，最终买进垃圾。在这个市场上，人们特别容易产生买家懊悔。

paragraphs.original: And it's also one that furnishes them plenty of excuses to gratify it. The public markets snap startup investing around like a whip. If the Chinese economy blows up tomorrow, all bets are off. But there are lots of surprises for individual startups too, and they tend to be concentrated around fundraising.
paragraphs.translated: 这同时也为他们提供了许多满足它的借口。公开市场像鞭子一样左右初创企业的投资。如果中国经济明天崩盘，所有的赌注都将落空。但对个别初创企业而言，也存在许多意外，而这些意外往往集中在融资环节。

paragraphs.original: Tomorrow a big competitor could appear, or you could get C&Ded, or your cofounder could quit. [16]Even a day's delay can bring news that causes an investor to change their mind. So when someone commits, get the money.
paragraphs.translated: 明天可能会出现一个强大的竞争对手，或者你可能会收到停止和终止函，或者你的联合创始人可能会辞职。[16]即使是一天的延迟，也可能带来导致投资者改变主意的消息。所以当有人承诺投资时，就立即拿到资金。

paragraphs.original: Knowing where you stand doesn't end when they say they'll invest. After they say yes, know what the timetable is for getting the money, and then babysit that process till it happens. Institutional investors have people in charge of wiring money, but you may have to hunt angels down in person to collect a check.Inexperienced investors are the ones most likely to get buyer's remorse.
paragraphs.translated: 知道自己的立场并不会在他们说要投资时就结束。在他们说同意后，要了解资金到位的时间表，然后监督整个过程直到资金到账。机构投资者会有专门负责转账的人，但你可能需要亲自去找天使投资人拿支票。缺乏经验的投资者最有可能会感到买家后悔。

paragraphs.original: Established ones have learned to treat saying yes as like diving off a diving board, and they also have more brand to preserve. But I've heard of cases of even top-tier VC firms welching on deals. Avoid investors who don't "lead."Since getting the first offer is most of the difficulty of fundraising, that should be part of your calculation of expected value when you start.
paragraphs.translated: 已有的企业学会了把说“是”看作是从跳板上跳水，同时他们也有更多的品牌需要维护。但我听说过即使是顶级的风险投资公司也会在交易上反悔。要避免那些不“领投”的投资者。由于获得第一份投资报价是融资过程中最困难的部分，因此在开始时，这应该是你计算预期价值的一部分。

paragraphs.original: You have to estimate not just the probability that an investor will say yes, but the probability that they'd be the first to say yes, and the latter is not simply a constant fraction of the former. Some investors are known for deciding quickly, and those are extra valuable early on.Conversely, an investor who will only invest once other investors have is worthless initially.
paragraphs.translated: 你不仅需要估计投资者说“是”的概率，还要估计他们成为第一个说“是”的人的概率，而后者并不是前者的简单固定比例。有些投资者以快速决策著称，这些人在初期尤为宝贵。相反，那些只有在其他投资者已经投资后才愿意投资的人在初期是毫无价值的。

paragraphs.original: And while most investors are influenced by how interested other investors are in you, there are some who have an explicit policy of only investing after other investors have. You can recognize this contemptible subspecies of investor because they often talk about "leads." They say that they don't lead, or that they'll invest once you have a lead.
paragraphs.translated: 而尽管大多数投资者会受到其他投资者对你兴趣的影响，但确实有一些投资者有明确的政策，只在其他投资者之后进行投资。你可以通过他们经常谈论“领投人”来识别这种可鄙的投资者亚种。他们会说他们不领投，或者他们会等到你有了领投人之后再投资。

paragraphs.original: Sometimes they even claim to be willing to lead themselves, by which they mean they won't invest till you get $x from other investors. (It's great if by "lead" they mean they'll invest unilaterally, and in addition will help you raise more.
paragraphs.translated: 有时他们甚至声称愿意领投，但他们的意思是你必须从其他投资者那里获得$x，他们才会投资。（如果他们所说的“领投”是指他们会单方面投资，并且还会帮助你筹集更多资金，那当然最好。）

paragraphs.original: What's lame is when they use the term to mean they won't invest unless you can raise more elsewhere.) [17]Where does this term "lead" come from? Up till a few years ago, startups raising money in phase 2 would usually raise equity rounds in which several investors invested at the same time using the same paperwork.
paragraphs.translated: 令人失望的是，当他们使用这个术语时，意味着除非你能在其他地方筹集到更多的资金，否则他们不会投资。）[17] 这个“领投”一词是从哪里来的？直到几年前，初创公司在第二阶段筹集资金时，通常会进行股权融资轮次，其中多个投资者同时使用相同的文件进行投资。

paragraphs.original: You'd negotiate the terms with one "lead" investor, and then all the others would sign the same documents and all the money change hands at the closing.Series A rounds still work that way, but things now work differently for most fundraising prior to the series A.
paragraphs.translated: 你将与一位“领投”投资者协商条款，然后其他所有投资者都会签署相同的文件，并在交易结束时所有资金完成交割。A轮融资仍然采用这种方式，但在A轮融资之前的大多数融资活动现在则有所不同。

paragraphs.original: Now there are rarely actual rounds before the A round, or leads for them. Now startups simply raise money from investors one at a time till they feel they have enough.Since there are no longer leads, why do investors use that term?
paragraphs.translated: 现在，在A轮融资之前很少有实际的融资轮次，或者为这些轮次寻找领投人。现在初创公司只是逐个地从投资者那里筹集资金，直到他们觉得自己筹集到足够的资金为止。既然现在已经没有领投人了，为什么投资者还在使用这个术语？

paragraphs.original: Because it's a more legitimate-sounding way of saying what they really mean. All they really mean is that their interest in you is a function of other investors' interest in you. I.e. the spectral signature of all mediocre investors.
paragraphs.translated: 因为他们觉得这样说听起来更正当。他们真正想表达的是，他们对你的兴趣取决于其他投资者对你的兴趣。也就是说，所有平庸投资者的共同特征。

paragraphs.original: But when phrased in terms of leads, it sounds like there is something structural and therefore legitimate about their behavior.When an investor tells you "I want to invest in you, but I don't lead," translate that in your mind to "No, except yes if you turn out to be a hot deal." And since that's the default opinion of any investor about any startup, they've essentially just told you nothing.When you first start fundraising, the expected value of an investor who won't "lead" is zero, so talk to such investors last if at all.
paragraphs.translated: 但是，当用“领投”来表述时，听起来他们的行为似乎具有某种结构性，因此是正当的。当投资者对你说“我想投资你，但我不会领投”时，在你脑海中将其理解为“不，除非你最终成为热门项目。”而由于这是任何投资者对任何初创公司的默认看法，他们实际上什么也没告诉你。当你刚开始筹集资金时，不会“领投”的投资者的期望价值为零，因此如果要与这样的投资者交谈，也应该放在最后。

paragraphs.original: Have multiple plans.Many investors will ask how much you're planning to raise. This question makes founders feel they should be planning to raise a specific amount. But in fact you shouldn't. It's a mistake to have fixed plans in an undertaking as unpredictable as fundraising.So why do investors ask how much you plan to raise?
paragraphs.translated: 准备多种方案。许多投资者会问你计划筹集多少资金。这个问题常常让创始人们觉得他们应该计划筹集一个特定的金额。但实际上你不应该这样。在像筹集资金这样不可预测的事业中，制定固定计划是一个错误。那么，为什么投资者会问你计划筹集多少资金呢？

paragraphs.original: For much the same reasons a salesperson in a store will ask "How much were you planning to spend?" if you walk in looking for a gift for a friend. You probably didn't have a precise amount in mind; you just want to find something good, and if it's inexpensive, so much the better.
paragraphs.translated: 出于同样的原因，如果你走进商店为朋友挑选礼物，店员通常会问：“您打算花多少钱？”你可能并没有一个确切的预算；你只是想找到一件不错的东西，如果价格便宜，那就更好了。

paragraphs.original: The salesperson asks you this not because you're supposed to have a plan to spend a specific amount, but so they can show you only things that cost the most you'll pay.Similarly, when investors ask how much you plan to raise, it's not because you're supposed to have a plan.
paragraphs.translated: 销售人员这样问并不是因为你应该有一个具体的花费计划，而是为了只向你展示那些你愿意支付的最高价格的商品。同样，当投资者询问你打算筹集多少资金时，这并不是因为你应该有一个具体的计划。

paragraphs.original: It's to see whether you'd be a suitable recipient for the size of investment they like to make, and also to judge your ambition, reasonableness, and how far you are along with fundraising.If you're a wizard at fundraising, you can say "We plan to raise a $7 million series A round, and we'll be accepting termsheets next tuesday." I've known a handful of founders who could pull that off without having VCs laugh in their faces.
paragraphs.translated: 这主要是为了看看你是否适合他们喜欢的投资规模，同时也会评估你的雄心、合理性以及你在融资过程中的进展。如果你在融资方面非常在行，你可以说：“我们计划进行一轮700万美元的A轮融资，并将在下周二开始接受条款书。”我认识一些创始人，他们能够做到这一点而不被风险投资家嘲笑。

paragraphs.original: But if you're in the inexperienced but earnest majority, the solution is analogous to the solution I recommend for pitching your startup: do the right thing and then just tell investors what you're doing.And the right strategy, in fundraising, is to have multiple plans depending on how much you can raise.
paragraphs.translated: 但如果你属于缺乏经验却真诚的大多数，解决方法类似于我为你的初创公司推介所推荐的方法：做正确的事，然后直接告诉投资者你在做什么。而在融资方面，正确的策略是根据你能筹集到的资金量来制定多个计划。

paragraphs.original: Ideally you should be able to tell investors something like: we can make it to profitability without raising any more money, but if we raise a few hundred thousand we can hire one or two smart friends, and if we raise a couple million, we can hire a whole engineering team, etc.Different plans match different investors.
paragraphs.translated: 理想情况下，你应该能够向投资者这样说明：我们可以在不筹集更多资金的情况下实现盈利，但如果筹集几十万美元，我们可以聘请一两位聪明的朋友；如果筹集几百万美元，我们可以组建一个完整的工程团队，等等。不同的计划适用于不同的投资者。

paragraphs.original: If you're talking to a VC firm that only does series A rounds (though there are few of those left), it would be a waste of time talking about any but your most expensive plan. Whereas if you're talking to an angel who invests $20k at a time and you haven't raised any money yet, you probably want to focus on your least expensive plan.If you're so fortunate as to have to think about the upper limit on what you should raise, a good rule of thumb is to multiply the number of people you want to hire times $15k times 18 months.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你正在与只做A轮融资的风险投资公司交谈（虽然现在这样的公司已经不多了），谈论除你最昂贵的计划之外的其他计划将是一种时间浪费。而如果你正在与一位每次投资2万美元的天使投资人交谈，而你还没有筹集到任何资金，那么你可能应该重点关注你最便宜的计划。如果你有幸需要考虑你应该筹集的资金上限，一个很好的经验法则是将你打算招聘的人数乘以15000美元再乘以18个月。

paragraphs.original: In most startups, nearly all the costs are a function of the number of people, and $15k per month is the conventional total cost (including benefits and even office space) per person. $15k per month is high, so don't actually spend that much.
paragraphs.translated: 在大多数初创公司中，几乎所有成本都是人员数量的函数，每人每月1.5万美元是包括福利甚至办公空间在内的常规总成本。每人每月1.5万美元是一个较高的标准，所以实际上不必花这么多。

paragraphs.original: But it's ok to use a high estimate when fundraising to add a margin for error. If you have additional expenses, like manufacturing, add in those at the end. Assuming you have none and you think you might hire 20 people, the most you'd want to raise is 20 x $15k x 18 = $5.4 million.
paragraphs.translated: 但在筹集资金时，使用较高的估计值以增加误差边际是可以的。如果你有额外的开支，比如制造成本，在最后加上这些。假设你没有额外的开支，并且你认为可能会雇佣20人，那么你最多想要筹集的资金是20人 x 1.5万美元 x 18个月 = 5400万美元。

paragraphs.original: [18] Underestimate how much you want.Though you can focus on different plans when talking to different types of investors, you should on the whole err on the side of underestimating the amount you hope to raise.For example, if you'd like to raise $500k, it's better to say initially that you're trying to raise $250k.
paragraphs.translated: [18] 低估你的需求。虽然在与不同类型的投资人交流时，你可以关注不同的计划，但总体上应该倾向于低估你希望筹集的金额。例如，如果你希望筹集500万美元，最初最好说你正在努力筹集250万美元。

paragraphs.original: Then when you reach $150k you're more than half done. That sends two useful signals to investors: that you're doing well, and that they have to decide quickly because you're running out of room. Whereas if you'd said you were raising $500k, you'd be less than a third done at $150k.
paragraphs.translated: 当你达到15万美元时，你就已经超过一半了。这向投资者发出了两个有用的信号：你做得很好，而且他们必须迅速做出决定，因为你剩下的空间不多了。而如果你说的是要筹集50万美元，那么在达到15万美元时，你还不到三分之一。

paragraphs.original: If fundraising stalled there for an appreciable time, you'd start to read as a failure.Saying initially that you're raising $250k doesn't limit you to raising that much. When you reach your initial target and you still have investor interest, you can just decide to raise more.
paragraphs.translated: 如果筹款在那里停滞了相当长的时间，你就会被视为失败。最初说你要筹集25万美元并不会限制你只能筹集这么多。当你达到最初的目标后，如果还有投资者感兴趣，你可以决定筹集更多。

paragraphs.original: Startups do that all the time. In fact, most startups that are very successful at fundraising end up raising more than they originally intended.I'm not saying you should lie, but that you should lower your expectations initially.
paragraphs.translated: 初创公司经常这样做。事实上，大多数在融资方面非常成功的初创公司最终筹集的资金都超过了他们最初的目标。我不是说你应该撒谎，而是建议你最初时应该降低期望值。

paragraphs.original: There is almost no downside in starting with a low number. It not only won't cap the amount you raise, but will on the whole tend to increase it.A good metaphor here is angle of attack. If you try to fly at too steep an angle of attack, you just stall.
paragraphs.translated: 从一个较低的数字开始几乎没有什么缺点。这不仅不会限制你筹集的资金总额，反而总体上会增加它。这里的一个好比喻是迎角。如果你尝试以过大的迎角飞行，飞机只会失速。

paragraphs.original: If you say right out of the gate that you want to raise a $5 million series A round, unless you're in a very strong position, you not only won't get that but won't get anything. Better to start at a low angle of attack, build up speed, and then gradually increase the angle if you want.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你一上来就说要筹集500万美元的A轮融资，除非你处于一个非常有利的位置，否则你不仅拿不到这笔钱，可能什么都拿不到。最好是先以低姿态切入，逐渐积累势头，然后再根据需要逐步提高目标。

paragraphs.original: Be profitable if you can.You will be in a much stronger position if your collection of plans includes one for raising zero dollars — i.e. if you can make it to profitability without raising any additional money.
paragraphs.translated: [翻译失败] Be profitable if you can.You will be in a much str...

paragraphs.original: Ideally you want to be able to say to investors "We'll succeed no matter what, but raising money will help us do it faster."There are many analogies between fundraising and dating, and this is one of the strongest.
paragraphs.translated: 理想情况下，你希望对投资者说：“无论怎样我们都会成功，但筹集资金将帮助我们更快地实现目标。”在融资和约会之间有许多相似之处，而这一点是最强烈的。

paragraphs.original: No one wants you if you seem desperate. And the best way not to seem desperate is not to be desperate. That's one reason we urge startups during YC to keep expenses low and to try to make it to ramen profitability before Demo Day.
paragraphs.translated: 没有人会喜欢显得很 desperation的人。而最好的不显得desperation的方法就是不要真的感到desperation。这就是为什么我们在YC期间敦促初创企业保持低开支，并试图在演示日之前实现拉面盈利。

paragraphs.original: Though it sounds slightly paradoxical, if you want to raise money, the best thing you can do is get yourself to the point where you don't need to.There are almost two distinct modes of fundraising: one in which founders who need money knock on doors seeking it, knowing that otherwise the company will die or at the very least people will have to be fired, and one in which founders who don't need money take some to grow faster than they could merely on their own revenues.
paragraphs.translated: 虽然听起来有些矛盾，但如果你想筹集资金，最好的办法就是让自己达到不需要资金的状态。几乎有两种截然不同的融资模式：一种是创始人因为需要资金而四处求援，知道如果得不到资金，公司就会倒闭，或者至少不得不裁员；另一种是创始人并不需要资金，但他们接受资金以实现比仅靠自身收入更快的增长。

paragraphs.original: To emphasize the distinction I'm going to name them: type A fundraising is when you don't need money, and type B fundraising is when you do.Inexperienced founders read about famous startups doing what was type A fundraising, and decide they should raise money too, since that seems to be how startups work.
paragraphs.translated: 为了强调这种区别，我将它们命名：A类融资是指你不需要资金的时候进行的融资，而B类融资是指你需要资金的时候进行的融资。缺乏经验的创始人读到著名的初创公司进行的是A类融资，便决定他们也应该融资，因为这似乎就是初创公司运作的方式。

paragraphs.original: Except when they raise money they don't have a clear path to profitability and are thus doing type B fundraising. And they are then surprised how difficult and unpleasant it is.Of course not all startups can make it to ramen profitability in a few months.
paragraphs.translated: 除了在他们筹钱时没有明确的盈利路径，因此正在进行B轮融资。然后他们对融资的艰难和不愉快感到惊讶。当然，并不是所有初创公司都能在几个月内达到仅够糊口的盈利状态。

paragraphs.original: And some that don't still manage to have the upper hand over investors, if they have some other advantage like extraordinary growth numbers or exceptionally formidable founders. But as time passes it gets increasingly difficult to fundraise from a position of strength without being profitable.
paragraphs.translated: 有些公司即使不盈利，仍然能够对投资者保持优势，如果它们有其他优势，比如惊人的增长数字或特别强大的创始人。但随着时间的推移，如果不盈利，要从强势地位筹集资金会变得越来越困难。

paragraphs.original: [19] Don't optimize for valuation.When you raise money, what should your valuation be? The most important thing to understand about valuation is that it's not that important.Founders who raise money at high valuations tend to be unduly proud of it.
paragraphs.translated: [19] 不要为了估值而优化。当你筹集资金时，你的估值应该是多少？关于估值最重要的一点是，它其实并不那么重要。那些以高估值筹集资金的创始人往往会不恰当地为此感到自豪。

paragraphs.original: Founders are often competitive people, and since valuation is usually the only visible number attached to a startup, they end up competing to raise money at the highest valuation. This is stupid, because fundraising is not the test that matters.
paragraphs.translated: 创始人往往是竞争心强的人，由于估值通常是初创企业唯一可见的数字，他们最终会为了以最高的估值筹集资金而竞争。这是愚蠢的，因为融资并不是决定性的考验。

paragraphs.original: The real test is revenue. Fundraising is just a means to that end. Being proud of how well you did at fundraising is like being proud of your college grades.Not only is fundraising not the test that matters, valuation is not even the thing to optimize about fundraising.
paragraphs.translated: 真正的考验是收入。融资只是达到这一目的的手段。为自己的融资成绩感到自豪，就像为自己的大学成绩感到自豪一样。融资并不是重要的考验，甚至估值也不是融资时需要优化的重点。

paragraphs.original: The number one thing you want from phase 2 fundraising is to get the money you need, so you can get back to focusing on the real test, the success of your company. Number two is good investors. Valuation is at best third.The empirical evidence shows just how unimportant it is.
paragraphs.translated: 第二阶段融资最重要的目标是获得所需的资金，这样你就可以重新专注于真正的考验，即公司的成功。其次是要有好的投资者。估值最多只能排在第三位。实证证据显示它有多么不重要。

paragraphs.original: Dropbox and Airbnb are the most successful companies we've funded so far, and they raised money after Y Combinator at premoney valuations of $4 million and $2.6 million respectively. Prices are so much higher now that if you can raise money at all you'll probably raise it at higher valuations than Dropbox and Airbnb.
paragraphs.translated: Dropbox 和 Airbnb 是我们迄今为止资助的最成功的公司，它们在 Y Combinator 之后分别以 4000 万美元和 2600 万美元的估值前融资。现在的价格高得多，如果你能够筹集到资金，那么你的估值很可能会高于 Dropbox 和 Airbnb 当时的估值。

paragraphs.original: So let that satisfy your competitiveness. You're doing better than Dropbox and Airbnb! At a test that doesn't matter.When you start fundraising, your initial valuation (or valuation cap) will be set by the deal you make with the first investor who commits.
paragraphs.translated: 那么就让这满足你的竞争心吧。你比Dropbox和Airbnb做得更好！在一项无关紧要的测试中。当你开始筹集资金时，你的初始估值（或估值上限）将由与第一位承诺投资的投资者达成的协议决定。

paragraphs.original: You can increase the price for later investors, if you get a lot of interest, but by default the valuation you got from the first investor becomes your asking price.So if you're raising money from multiple investors, as most companies do in phase 2, you have to be careful to avoid raising the first from an over-eager investor at a price you won't be able to sustain.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你获得了很多兴趣，可以提高对后来投资者的价格，但默认情况下，从第一位投资者那里获得的估值将成为你的要价。因此，如果你像大多数公司在第二阶段那样从多个投资者那里筹集资金，必须小心，避免从过于热切的首位投资者那里以一个你无法维持的价格筹集资金。

paragraphs.original: You can of course lower your price if you need to (in which case you should give the same terms to investors who invested earlier at a higher price), but you may lose a bunch of leads in the process of realizing you need to do this.What you can do if you have eager first investors is raise money from them on an uncapped convertible note with an MFN clause.
paragraphs.translated: 当然，如果你需要的话可以降低价格（在这种情况下，你应该给予之前以较高价格投资的投资者相同的条件），但在意识到需要这样做时，你可能会失去很多潜在客户。如果你有一批急切的首批投资者，你可以通过无上限可转换债券并附带MFN条款从他们那里筹集资金。

paragraphs.original: This is essentially a way of saying that the valuation cap of the note will be determined by the next investors you raise money from.It will be easier to raise money at a lower valuation. It shouldn't be, but it is.

paragraphs.original: Since phase 2 prices vary at most 10x and the big successes generate returns of at least 100x, investors should pick startups entirely based on their estimate of the probability that the company will be a big success and hardly at all on price.
paragraphs.translated: 由于第二阶段的价格差异最多为10倍，而大获成功的企业能带来至少100倍的回报，投资者应该完全根据他们对该公司能否大获成功的概率估计来选择初创企业，而几乎不应考虑价格。

paragraphs.original: But although it's a mistake for investors to care about price, a significant number do. A startup that investors seem to like but won't invest in at a cap of $x will have an easier time at $x/2. [20] Yes/no before valuation.Some investors want to know what your valuation is before they even talk to you about investing.
paragraphs.translated: 但尽管投资者关注价格是个错误，仍有不少人这么做。一家初创公司即使受到投资者的青睐，但如果他们不愿意在估值为x美元的情况下投资，那么在估值为x/2美元时，这家公司的融资会容易得多。[20] 在估值之前先问是否愿意投资。有些投资者甚至在与你讨论投资之前，就想知道你的估值是多少。

paragraphs.original: If your valuation has already been set by a prior investment at a specific valuation or cap, you can tell them that number. But if it isn't set because you haven't closed anyone yet, and they try to push you to name a price, resist doing so.
paragraphs.translated: 如果您的估值已经由之前的投资者以特定的估值或上限设定，您可以告诉他们这个数字。但如果还没有确定，因为您尚未完成任何融资，而他们试图逼您报价，您应该抵制这样做。

paragraphs.original: If this would be the first investor you've closed, then this could be the tipping point of fundraising. That means closing this investor is the first priority, and you need to get the conversation onto that instead of being dragged sideways into a discussion of price.Fortunately there is a way to avoid naming a price in this situation.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你这是第一次成功争取到投资者，那么这可能是融资的关键转折点。这意味着敲定这位投资者是首要任务，你需要把对话重点放在这一点上，而不是被牵扯到价格讨论中。幸运的是，在这种情况下有一种方法可以避免提及价格。

paragraphs.original: And it is not just a negotiating trick; it's how you (both) should be operating. Tell them that valuation is not the most important thing to you and that you haven't thought much about it, that you are looking for investors you want to partner with and who want to partner with you, and that you should talk first about whether they want to invest at all.
paragraphs.translated: 这不仅仅是一种谈判技巧；这是你们双方应该采取的行动方式。告诉他们，估值对你来说并不是最重要的事情，你对此并没有过多考虑，你是在寻找愿意与你合作的投资者，同时也希望他们是希望与你合作的。你们应该首先讨论他们是否有投资的意愿。

paragraphs.original: Then if they decide they do want to invest, you can figure out a price. But first things first.Since valuation isn't that important and getting fundraising rolling is, we usually tell founders to give the first investor who commits as low a price as they need to.
paragraphs.translated: 如果他们决定要投资，你们可以商定一个价格。但首先得优先处理最重要的事情。由于估值并不是那么重要，而启动融资过程才是关键，我们通常建议创始人给第一个承诺投资的投资者提供他们所需的最低价格。

paragraphs.original: This is a safe technique so long as you combine it with the next one. [21] Beware "valuation sensitive" investors.Occasionally you'll encounter investors who describe themselves as "valuation sensitive." What this means in practice is that they are compulsive negotiators who will suck up a lot of your time trying to push your price down.
paragraphs.translated: 只要与下一种方法结合使用，这是一种安全的技巧。[21] 警惕“估值敏感”的投资者。有时你会遇到自称“估值敏感”的投资者，实际上这意味着他们是强迫性谈判者，会花大量时间试图压低你的价格。

paragraphs.original: You should therefore never approach such investors first. While you shouldn't chase high valuations, you also don't want your valuation to be set artificially low because the first investor who committed happened to be a compulsive negotiator.
paragraphs.translated: 因此，你不应该首先接触这样的投资者。虽然你不应该追求过高的估值，但你也不希望因为第一个承诺投资的人碰巧是个强迫性谈判者，而导致你的估值被人为压低。

paragraphs.original: Some such investors have value, but the time to approach them is near the end of fundraising, when you're in a position to say "this is the price everyone else has paid; take it or leave it" and not mind if they leave it.
paragraphs.translated: 有些这样的投资者确实有价值，但接触他们的时间应该是在融资接近尾声时，那时你可以对他们说“这是其他所有人支付的价格，要么接受，要么放弃”，而且你不会介意他们选择放弃。

paragraphs.original: This way, you'll not only get market price, but it will also take less time.Ideally you know which investors have a reputation for being "valuation sensitive" and can postpone dealing with them till last, but occasionally one you didn't know about will pop up early on.
paragraphs.translated: 这样，你不仅可以获得市场价格，还能节省时间。理想情况下，你知道哪些投资者因“对估值敏感”而有良好声誉，可以将与他们的交涉推迟到最后，但偶尔也会有你不知道的投资者在早期冒出来。

paragraphs.original: The rule of doing breadth first search weighted by expected value already tells you what to do in this case: slow down your interactions with them.There are a handful of investors who will try to invest at a lower valuation even when your price has already been set.
paragraphs.translated: 按照预期值加权的广度优先搜索规则已经告诉你在这种情况下该怎么做：减缓与他们的互动。有一些投资者即使在你的价格已经确定的情况下，仍会试图以较低的估值进行投资。

paragraphs.original: Lowering your price is a backup plan you resort to when you discover you've let the price get set too high to close all the money you need. So you'd only want to talk to this sort of investor if you were about to do that anyway.
paragraphs.translated: 降低价格是你在发现自己设定的价格过高，无法获得所需全部资金时采取的备用计划。因此，你只有在打算这样做时，才应该与这类投资者交谈。

paragraphs.original: But since investor meetings have to be arranged at least a few days in advance and you can't predict when you'll need to resort to lowering your price, this means in practice that you should approach this type of investor last if at all.If you're surprised by a lowball offer, treat it as a backup offer and delay responding to it.
paragraphs.translated: 但由于投资者会议至少需要提前几天安排，而你无法预测何时需要降低价格，这意味着在实际操作中，如果要接触这种类型的投资者，应该最后再考虑。如果你收到一个出乎意料的低价报价，应将其视为备选方案，并推迟回应。

paragraphs.original: When someone makes an offer in good faith, you have a moral obligation to respond in a reasonable time. But lowballing you is a dick move that should be met with the corresponding countermove. Accept offers greedily.I'm a little leery of using the term "greedily" when writing about fundraising lest non-programmers misunderstand me, but a greedy algorithm is simply one that doesn't try to look into the future.
paragraphs.translated: 当某人以善意提出报价时，你有道德义务在合理的时间内做出回应。但如果对方试图以远低于合理价值的价格压价，那这就是一种卑鄙的行为，你应该用相应的对策回应。贪婪地接受报价。我有点担心在谈论融资时使用“贪婪地”这个词，害怕非程序员会误解我，但贪婪算法其实只是指那种不试图预测未来的算法。

paragraphs.original: A greedy algorithm takes the best of the options in front of it right now. And that is how startups should approach fundraising in phases 2 and later. Don't try to look into the future because (a) the future is unpredictable, and indeed in this business you're often being deliberately misled about it and (b) your first priority in fundraising should be to get it finished and get back to work anyway.If someone makes you an acceptable offer, take it.
paragraphs.translated: 贪婪算法会选择当前最佳的选项。创业公司在进行第二阶段及后续的融资时也应该采取这种态度。不要试图预测未来，因为（a）未来是不可预测的，而且在这个行业中，你经常会被故意误导；（b）在融资过程中，你的首要任务是尽快完成融资，然后回到工作中。如果有人给你一个可接受的报价，就接受它。

paragraphs.original: If you have multiple incompatible offers, take the best. Don't reject an acceptable offer in the hope of getting a better one in the future.These simple rules cover a wide variety of cases. If you're raising money from many investors, roll them up as they say yes.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你有多个不兼容的报价，选择最好的那个。不要因为希望将来能获得更好的报价而拒绝一个可以接受的报价。这些简单的规则适用于各种情况。如果你正在向多个投资者募集资金，当他们同意时，就将他们纳入。

paragraphs.original: As you start to feel you've raised enough, the threshold for acceptable will start to get higher.In practice offers exist for stretches of time, not points. So when you get an acceptable offer that would be incompatible with others (e.g.
paragraphs.translated: 当你开始觉得已经筹集到了足够的资金时，可接受的门槛就会变得更高。实际上，报价是存在于一段时间内的，而不是仅仅在某个时间点上。因此，当你收到一个与其他选项不兼容的可接受报价时（例如：

paragraphs.original: an offer to invest most of the money you need), you can tell the other investors you're talking to that you have an offer good enough to accept, and give them a few days to make their own. This could lose you some that might have made an offer if they had more time.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你得到了一个愿意投资你所需大部分资金的offer，你可以告诉其他正在洽谈的投资者，你已经收到了一个足够好的offer，并给他们几天时间来做出自己的决定。这可能会让你失去一些本可能会在有更多时间的情况下做出offer的投资者。

paragraphs.original: But by definition you don't care; the initial offer was acceptable.Some investors will try to prevent others from having time to decide by giving you an "exploding" offer, meaning one that's only valid for a few days.
paragraphs.translated: 但根据定义，您并不在意；最初的报价是可以接受的。一些投资者会通过给出一个“过期失效”的报价来防止其他人有时间做决定，这意味着该报价只在几天内有效。

paragraphs.original: Offers from the very best investors explode less frequently and less rapidly — Fred Wilson never gives exploding offers, for example — because they're confident you'll pick them. But lower-tier investors sometimes give offers with very short fuses, because they believe no one who had other options would choose them.
paragraphs.translated: 最顶级投资者的报价爆炸得不那么频繁，也不那么迅速——例如，Fred Wilson从不给出爆炸性报价——因为他们相信你会选择他们。但较低级别的投资者有时会给出非常紧迫的报价，因为他们认为如果有其他选择的人是不会选择他们的。

paragraphs.original: A deadline of three working days is acceptable. You shouldn't need more than that if you've been talking to investors in parallel. But a deadline any shorter is a sign you're dealing with a sketchy investor.
paragraphs.translated: 三个工作日的截止期限是可以接受的。如果你一直在与投资者并行沟通，那么不应该需要更多时间。但如果截止期限更短，那就表明你可能在 dealing with 一个不太可靠的投资者。

paragraphs.original: You can usually call their bluff, and you may need to. [22]It might seem that instead of accepting offers greedily, your goal should be to get the best investors as partners. That is certainly a good goal, but in phase 2 "get the best investors" only rarely conflicts with "accept offers greedily," because the best investors don't usually take any longer to decide than the others.
paragraphs.translated: 你通常可以识破他们的虚张声势，而且你可能需要这样做。[22]这可能看起来，与其贪婪地接受报价，你的目标应该是吸引最好的投资者作为合作伙伴。这当然是一个很好的目标，但在第二阶段，“吸引最好的投资者”很少会与“贪婪地接受报价”产生冲突，因为最好的投资者通常不会比其他投资者花更多时间来做决定。

paragraphs.original: The only case where the two strategies give conflicting advice is when you have to forgo an offer from an acceptable investor to see if you'll get an offer from a better one. If you talk to investors in parallel and push back on exploding offers with excessively short deadlines, that will almost never happen.
paragraphs.translated: 唯一两种策略会给出相互矛盾建议的情况是，你必须放弃一个可接受投资者的报价，以等待看是否会有一个更好的报价出现。如果你同时与投资者接触，并对那些期限过短的立即生效报价进行拖延，这种情况几乎不会发生。

paragraphs.original: But if it does, "get the best investors" is in the average case bad advice. The best investors are also the most selective, because they get their pick of all the startups. They reject nearly everyone they talk to, which means in the average case it's a bad trade to exchange a definite offer from an acceptable investor for a potential offer from a better one.(The situation is different in phase 1.
paragraphs.translated: 但如果真是这样，“找到最好的投资者”在一般情况下就是错误的建议。最好的投资者同时也是最挑剔的，因为他们可以挑选所有的初创公司。他们几乎会拒绝与他们交谈的每一个人，这意味着在一般情况下，用一个可靠投资者的确定性报价换取一个更好投资者的潜在报价是不划算的。（第一阶段的情况则不同。

paragraphs.original: You can't apply to all the incubators in parallel, because some offset their schedules to prevent this. In phase 1, "accept offers greedily" and "get the best investors" do conflict, so if you want to apply to multiple incubators, you should do it in such a way that the ones you want most decide first.)Sometimes when you're raising money from multiple investors, a series A will emerge out of those conversations, and these rules even cover what to do in that case.
paragraphs.translated: 你不能同时申请所有的孵化器，因为有些孵化器会错开时间表以防止这种情况。在第一阶段，“贪婪地接受 offer”和“获得最好的投资者”之间存在冲突，所以如果你想要申请多个孵化器，应该以你最想要的那些孵化器先做出决定的方式来申请。有时，当你从多个投资者那里筹集资金时，A 轮融资可能会从这些交谈中浮现出来，这些规则甚至涵盖了在这种情况下该怎么做。

paragraphs.original: When an investor starts to talk to you about a series A, keep taking smaller investments till they actually give you a termsheet. There's no practical difficulty. If the smaller investments are on convertible notes, they'll just convert into the series A round.
paragraphs.translated: 当投资者开始和你谈论A轮融资时，继续接受小额投资，直到他们真正给你一份投资条款书。这在实际操作中没有困难。如果小额投资是通过可转换债券进行的，它们会自动转换为A轮融资的一部分。

paragraphs.original: The series A investor won't like having all these other random investors as bedfellows, but if it bothers them so much they should get on with giving you a termsheet. Till they do, you don't know for sure they will, and the greedy algorithm tells you what to do.
paragraphs.translated: A轮投资者不会喜欢有这么多其他随机投资者作为同伴，但如果这让他们如此烦恼，他们就应该赶紧给你一份条款书。在他们这样做之前，你不能确定他们是否会这样做，而贪心算法会告诉你该怎么做。

paragraphs.original: [23] Don't sell more than 25% in phase 2.If you do well, you will probably raise a series A round eventually. I say probably because things are changing with series A rounds. Startups may start to skip them.
paragraphs.translated: [23] 在第二阶段不要出售超过25%的股份。如果你表现良好，最终可能会上市A轮融资。我说“可能”是因为A轮融资的情况正在发生变化。初创公司可能会开始跳过这一轮。

paragraphs.original: But only one company we've funded has so far, so tentatively assume the path to huge passes through an A round. [24]Which means you should avoid doing things in earlier rounds that will mess up raising an A round.
paragraphs.translated: 但到目前为止，我们资助的公司中只有一家初步走上了通往大规模成功的A轮融资之路。[24]这意味着你应该避免在早期轮次中做可能影响A轮融资的事情。

paragraphs.original: For example, if you've sold more than about 40% of your company total, it starts to get harder to raise an A round, because VCs worry there will not be enough stock left to keep the founders motivated.Our rule of thumb is not to sell more than 25% in phase 2, on top of whatever you sold in phase 1, which should be less than 15%.
paragraphs.translated: 例如，如果你已经出售了公司大约40%以上的股份，筹集A轮融资就会变得更加困难，因为风险投资家担心剩下的股份不足以保持创始人的积极性。我们的经验法则是，在第二阶段不要出售超过25%的股份，这还要加上你在第一阶段出售的股份，该阶段的出售比例应低于15%。

paragraphs.original: If you're raising money on uncapped notes, you'll have to guess what the eventual equity round valuation might be. Guess conservatively.(Since the goal of this rule is to avoid messing up the series A, there's obviously an exception if you end up raising a series A in phase 2, as a handful of startups do.) Have one person handle fundraising.If you have multiple founders, pick one to handle fundraising so the other(s) can keep working on the company.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你在通过无上限票据筹集资金，你必须猜测最终股权轮融资的估值可能会是多少。保守地估计。（由于这条规则的目的是避免影响A轮融资，因此如果你在第二阶段成功筹集到A轮融资，就像一些初创公司那样，就有一个例外。）指定一个人负责融资。如果你有多个创始人，选择一个人来负责融资，以便其他人可以继续专注于公司的发展。

paragraphs.original: And since the danger of fundraising is not the time taken up by the actual meetings but that it becomes the top idea in your mind, the founder who handles fundraising should make a conscious effort to insulate the other founder(s) from the details of the process.
paragraphs.translated: 而且，融资的危险不在于实际会议所占用的时间，而在于它会成为你脑海中最重要的事情，因此负责融资的创始人应该有意识地让其他创始人免受这一过程细节的影响。

paragraphs.original: [25](If the founders mistrust one another, this could cause some friction. But if the founders mistrust one another, you have worse problems to worry about than how to organize fundraising.)The founder who handles fundraising should be the CEO, who should in turn be the most formidable of the founders.
paragraphs.translated: 如果创始人之间互不信任，这可能会引起一些摩擦。但如果创始人之间互不信任，你将面临的问题远比如何组织融资更为严重。处理融资事宜的应该是首席执行官，而首席执行官应该是创始人中最强势的一位。

paragraphs.original: Even if the CEO is a programmer and another founder is a salesperson? Yes. If you happen to be that type of founding team, you're effectively a single founder when it comes to fundraising.It's ok to bring all the founders to meet an investor who will invest a lot, and who needs this meeting as the final step before deciding.
paragraphs.translated: 即使CEO是程序员，另一位创始人是销售人员？是的。如果你的创始团队是这种情况，那么在融资方面，你们实际上相当于单个创始人。如果某个投资者将要进行大额投资，并且需要这次会议作为最后的决定步骤，那么带所有创始人去见这位投资者是可以的。

paragraphs.original: But wait till that point. Introducing an investor to your cofounder(s) should be like introducing a girl/boyfriend to your parents — something you do only when things reach a certain stage of seriousness.Even if there are still one or more founders focusing on the company during fundraising, growth will slow.
paragraphs.translated: 但要等到那个时机。向你的联合创始人介绍投资者应该像向父母介绍男女朋友一样——只有当关系达到一定严肃程度时才这样做。即使在融资期间仍有一名或多名创始人专注于公司，增长也会放缓。

paragraphs.original: But try to get as much growth as you can, because fundraising is a segment of time, not a point, and what happens to the company during that time affects the outcome. If your numbers grow significantly between two investor meetings, investors will be hot to close, and if your numbers are flat or down they'll start to get cold feet.
paragraphs.translated: 但要尽可能多地实现增长，因为融资是一个时间段，而不是一个时间点，在这段时间内公司的发展情况会影响融资的结果。如果你的数字在两次投资者会议之间有显著增长，投资者会急于完成投资；而如果你的数字停滞不前或下降，他们就会开始犹豫不决。

paragraphs.original: You'll need an executive summary and (maybe) a deck.Traditionally phase 2 fundraising consists of presenting a slide deck in person to investors. Sequoia describes what such a deck should contain, and since they're the customer you can take their word for it.I say "traditionally" because I'm ambivalent about decks, and (though perhaps this is wishful thinking) they seem to be on the way out.
paragraphs.translated: 你需要准备一份执行摘要和（或许）一份演示文稿。传统上，第二阶段的融资活动包括亲自向投资者展示幻灯片。红杉资本描述了这样的演示文稿应包含的内容，既然他们是客户，你可以相信他们的建议。我说“传统上”是因为我对演示文稿持保留态度，而且（尽管这可能是我的一厢情愿）它们似乎正在逐渐被淘汰。

paragraphs.original: A lot of the most successful startups we fund never make decks in phase 2. They just talk to investors and explain what they plan to do. Fundraising usually takes off fast for the startups that are most successful at it, and they're thus able to excuse themselves by saying that they haven't had time to make a deck.You'll also want an executive summary, which should be no more than a page long and describe in the most matter of fact language what you plan to do, why it's a good idea, and what progress you've made so far.
paragraphs.translated: 我们资助的许多最成功的初创公司在第二阶段通常不会制作演示文稿。他们只是与投资者交谈，解释他们的计划。对于最擅长融资的初创公司，融资进程通常会迅速启动，因此他们能够以没有时间为由婉拒制作演示文稿。你还需要准备一份执行摘要，长度不应超过一页，用最直白的语言描述你的计划、为什么这是一个好主意，以及到目前为止你取得了哪些进展。

paragraphs.original: The point of the summary is to remind the investor (who may have met many startups that day) what you talked about.Assume that if you give someone a copy of your deck or executive summary, it will be passed on to whoever you'd least like to have it.
paragraphs.translated: 摘要的目的是提醒投资者（他们当天可能已经见过很多创业公司）你们讨论的内容。假设如果你给别人一份你的演示文稿或执行摘要，它可能会被传递给最不想让它落到的人手中。

paragraphs.original: But don't refuse on that account to give copies to investors you meet. You just have to treat such leaks as a cost of doing business. In practice it's not that high a cost. Though founders are rightly indignant when their plans get leaked to competitors, I can't think of a startup whose outcome has been affected by it.Sometimes an investor will ask you to send them your deck and/or executive summary before they decide whether to meet with you.
paragraphs.translated: 但不要因此拒绝向你遇到的投资者提供副本。你只需要将这种泄露视为做生意的成本之一。实际上，这种成本并不高。虽然创始人在计划泄露给竞争对手时感到义愤填膺，但我想不到有哪家创业公司的结果因此受到影响。有时，投资者会要求你在决定是否与你会面之前发送你的演示文稿和/或执行摘要。

paragraphs.original: I wouldn't do that. It's a sign they're not really interested. Stop fundraising when it stops working.When do you stop fundraising? Ideally when you've raised enough. But what if you haven't raised as much as you'd like?
paragraphs.translated: 我不会那么做的。这表明他们并不是真的感兴趣。当融资不再奏效时就停止。你什么时候停止融资？理想情况下，当你筹集到足够的资金时。但如果筹集的资金没有你希望的那么多呢？

paragraphs.original: When do you give up?It's hard to give general advice about this, because there have been cases of startups that kept trying to raise money even when it seemed hopeless, and miraculously succeeded. But what I usually tell founders is to stop fundraising when you start to get a lot of air in the straw.
paragraphs.translated: 你什么时候放弃？对于这个问题很难给出普遍的建议，因为确实有初创公司在看似毫无希望的情况下仍然继续努力筹集资金，并奇迹般地成功了。但我通常告诉创始人的是，当你开始感觉到吸管里有很多空气时，就应该停止筹集资金了。

paragraphs.original: When you're drinking through a straw, you can tell when you get to the end of the liquid because you start to get a lot of air in the straw. When your fundraising options run out, they usually run out in the same way.
paragraphs.translated: 当你用吸管喝饮料时，当饮料快喝完时，你会感觉到吸管里开始有很多空气。当你筹集资金的途径用尽时，通常也是以这种方式结束的。

paragraphs.original: Don't keep sucking on the straw if you're just getting air. It's not going to get better. Don't get addicted to fundraising.Fundraising is a chore for most founders, but some find it more interesting than working on their startup.
paragraphs.translated: 如果吸管里只有空气，就不要继续吸了。这样不会有任何改善。不要对募资上瘾。对大多数创始人来说，募资是一项苦差事，但有些人却觉得这比经营他们的创业公司更有趣。

paragraphs.original: The work at an early stage startup often consists of unglamorous schleps. Whereas fundraising, when it's going well, can be quite the opposite. Instead of sitting in your grubby apartment listening to users complain about bugs in your software, you're being offered millions of dollars by famous investors over lunch at a nice restaurant.
paragraphs.translated: 早期创业公司的工作往往包含许多不那么光鲜的任务。而融资顺利时，则完全是另一番景象。你不再坐在破旧的公寓里听用户抱怨软件的漏洞，而是会在一家高档餐厅的午餐上，被著名投资者开出数百万美元的支票。

paragraphs.original: [26]The danger of fundraising is particularly acute for people who are good at it. It's always fun to work on something you're good at. If you're one of these people, beware. Fundraising is not what will make your company successful.
paragraphs.translated: [26]对于那些擅长融资的人来说，融资的危险尤为严重。做自己擅长的事情总是很有趣的。如果你是这样的人，要当心。融资并不能让你的公司成功。

paragraphs.original: Listening to users complain about bugs in your software is what will make you successful. And the big danger of getting addicted to fundraising is not merely that you'll spend too long on it or raise too much money.
paragraphs.translated: 倾听用户对您软件中漏洞的抱怨会让您走向成功。而沉迷于融资的最大危险不仅仅在于您会花费太多时间在上面或筹集过多的资金。

paragraphs.original: It's that you'll start to think of yourself as being already successful, and lose your taste for the schleps you need to undertake to actually be successful. Startups can be destroyed by this.When I see a startup with young founders that is fabulously successful at fundraising, I mentally decrease my estimate of the probability that they'll succeed.
paragraphs.translated: 你会开始认为自己已经成功了，从而失去了为了真正成功所需要经历的艰难过程的兴趣。初创公司可能会因此而毁于一旦。当我看到一家由年轻创始人领导的初创公司在融资方面取得巨大成功时，我就会在心里降低他们成功概率的预期。

paragraphs.original: The press may be writing about them as if they'd been anointed as the next Google, but I'm thinking "this is going to end badly." Don't raise too much.Though only a handful of startups have to worry about this, it is possible to raise too much.
paragraphs.translated: 媒体可能将他们描绘成下一个谷歌的接班人，但我认为“这将以糟糕收场。”不要募集太多资金。虽然只有少数初创公司需要担心这一点，但确实存在募集过多资金的可能性。

paragraphs.original: The dangers of raising too much are subtle but insidious. One is that it will set impossibly high expectations. If you raise an excessive amount of money, it will be at a high valuation, and the danger of raising money at too high a valuation is that you won't be able to increase it sufficiently the next time you raise money.A company's valuation is expected to rise each time it raises money.
paragraphs.translated: 筹集过多资金的风险是微妙但具有腐蚀性的。其中一个风险是会设定不可能达到的高期望。如果你筹集了过多的资金，那通常是在一个很高的估值下进行的，而以过高估值筹集资金的危险在于，下次筹集资金时你可能无法使估值充分增长。通常情况下，每次公司筹集资金时，其估值都被期望有所上升。

paragraphs.original: If not it's a sign of a company in trouble, which makes you unattractive to investors. So if you raise money in phase 2 at a post-money valuation of $30 million, the pre-money valuation of your next round, if you want to raise one, is going to have to be at least $50 million.
paragraphs.translated: 如果不是这样，就表明公司存在问题，这会使你对投资者失去吸引力。因此，如果你在第二阶段以3000万美元的投后估值融资，那么如果你打算进行下一轮融资，其投前估值至少需要达到5000万美元。

paragraphs.original: And you have to be doing really, really well to raise money at $50 million.It's very dangerous to let the competitiveness of your current round set the performance threshold you have to meet to raise your next one, because the two are only loosely coupled.But the money itself may be more dangerous than the valuation.
paragraphs.translated: 你必须表现得非常非常出色，才能在5000万美元的估值下筹集到资金。让当前轮融资的竞争性决定你下一轮融资所需的业绩门槛是非常危险的，因为这两者之间的联系其实是很松散的。但资金本身可能比估值更加危险。

paragraphs.original: The more you raise, the more you spend, and spending a lot of money can be disastrous for an early stage startup. Spending a lot makes it harder to become profitable, and perhaps even worse, it makes you more rigid, because the main way to spend money is people, and the more people you have, the harder it is to change directions.
paragraphs.translated: 你筹集的资金越多，支出也就越多，而大量的支出对早期的初创公司来说可能是灾难性的。高额的支出使公司更难实现盈利，更糟糕的是，它还会使公司变得更加僵化，因为花钱的主要方式是雇人，而员工越多，改变方向就越困难。

paragraphs.original: So if you do raise a huge amount of money, don't spend it. (You will find that advice almost impossible to follow, so hot will be the money burning a hole in your pocket, but I feel obliged at least to try.) Be nice.Startups raising money occasionally alienate investors by seeming arrogant.
paragraphs.translated: 所以，如果你确实筹集到了一大笔钱，也不要乱花。(你会发现这个建议几乎不可能遵守，因为钱在口袋里烧得你心里发痒，但我觉得至少有义务试一试。) 要友好。初创公司在筹集资金时偶尔会因为显得傲慢而疏远投资者。

paragraphs.original: Sometimes because they are arrogant, and sometimes because they're noobs clumsily attempting to mimic the toughness they've observed in experienced founders.It's a mistake to behave arrogantly to investors.
paragraphs.translated: 有时是因为他们傲慢，有时则是因为他们是新手，笨拙地模仿他们所见到的经验丰富的创始人所表现出的坚韧。对投资者表现出傲慢是一种错误。

paragraphs.original: While there are certain situations in which certain investors like certain kinds of arrogance, investors vary greatly in this respect, and a flick of the whip that will bring one to heel will make another roar with indignation.
paragraphs.translated: 虽然在某些情况下，某些投资者会喜欢某种傲慢，但投资者在这方面有很大的差异，一种让他们屈服的鞭策可能会让另一个愤怒地咆哮。

paragraphs.original: The only safe strategy is never to seem arrogant at all.That will require some diplomacy if you follow the advice I've given here, because the advice I've given is essentially how to play hardball back.
paragraphs.translated: 唯一的安全策略是永远不要显得傲慢。如果你遵循了我给出的建议，这将需要一些外交手腕，因为我的建议本质上是如何强硬回应。

paragraphs.original: When you refuse to meet an investor because you're not in fundraising mode, or slow down your interactions with an investor who moves too slow, or treat a contingent offer as the no it actually is and then, by accepting offers greedily, end up leaving that investor out, you're going to be doing things investors don't like.
paragraphs.translated: 当你因为不在融资模式而拒绝与投资者会面，或者因为某个投资者动作太慢而减少与他的互动，或者把一个附条件的报价当作实际上的拒绝，然后由于贪婪地接受报价，最终把这个投资者排除在外，你就是在做投资者不喜欢的事情。

paragraphs.original: So you must cushion the blow with soft words. At YC we tell startups they can blame us. And now that I've written this, everyone else can blame me if they want. That plus the inexperience card should work in most situations: sorry, we think you're great, but PG said startups shouldn't ___, and since we're new to fundraising, we feel like we have to play it safe.The danger of behaving arrogantly is greatest when you're doing well.
paragraphs.translated: 所以你必须用温和的话语来缓和冲击。在YC，我们告诉初创公司他们可以责怪我们。现在我写了这篇文章，其他人如果愿意也可以责怪我。再加上缺乏经验这一点，应该在大多数情况下都能奏效：对不起，我们认为你很棒，但PG说初创公司不应该____，由于我们对融资还不熟悉，我们觉得必须谨慎行事。当你一切顺利时，表现出傲慢的危险是最大的。

paragraphs.original: When everyone wants you, it's hard not to let it go to your head. Especially if till recently no one wanted you. But restrain yourself. The startup world is a small place, and startups have lots of ups and downs.
paragraphs.translated: 当每个人都想要你的时候，很难不让这冲昏你的头脑。特别是如果直到最近还无人问津。但请克制自己。创业圈是一个很小的圈子，而创业公司经历的起伏跌宕也很多。

paragraphs.original: This is a domain where it's more true than usual that pride goeth before a fall. [27]Be nice when investors reject you as well. The best investors are not wedded to their initial opinion of you. If they reject you in phase 2 and you end up doing well, they'll often invest in phase 3.
paragraphs.translated: 在这个领域，骄傲确实常常导致失败。[27]即使投资者拒绝了你，也要保持友好。最好的投资者不会固守他们最初的判断。如果他们在第二阶段拒绝了你，而你最终表现良好，他们通常会在第三阶段投资。

paragraphs.original: In fact investors who reject you are some of your warmest leads for future fundraising. Any investor who spent significant time deciding probably came close to saying yes. Often you have some internal champion who only needs a little more evidence to convince the skeptics.
paragraphs.translated: 事实上，拒绝你的投资者可能是你未来融资时最热切的潜在支持者。任何花费大量时间作出决定的投资者，可能都曾接近于同意投资。通常情况下，你内部有一位倡导者，只需要再多一点证据就能说服怀疑者。

paragraphs.original: So it's wise not merely to be nice to investors who reject you, but (unless they behaved badly) to treat it as the beginning of a relationship. The bar will be higher next time.Assume the money you raise in phase 2 will be the last you ever raise.
paragraphs.translated: 因此，明智的做法不仅是对拒绝你的投资者保持友好，而且（除非他们行为不当）应将其视为一段关系的开始。下一次的标准会更高。假设你在第二阶段筹集的资金将是最后一笔。

paragraphs.original: You must make it to profitability on this money if you can.Over the past several years, the investment community has evolved from a strategy of anointing a small number of winners early and then supporting them for years to a strategy of spraying money at early stage startups and then ruthlessly culling them at the next stage.
paragraphs.translated: 你必须尽可能地使这笔资金实现盈利。在过去几年中，投资界已经从早期选定少数赢家并长期支持他们的策略，转变为向早期初创公司大量投入资金，然后在下一阶段无情地淘汰他们的策略。

paragraphs.original: This is probably the optimal strategy for investors. It's too hard to pick winners early on. Better to let the market do it for you. But it often comes as a surprise to startups how much harder it is to raise money in phase 3.When your company is only a couple months old, all it has to be is a promising experiment that's worth funding to see how it turns out.
paragraphs.translated: 这可能是投资者的最佳策略。早期挑选赢家太难了。不如让市场来决定。但对初创公司来说，往往会在第三阶段融资时感到意外，因为那时融资会变得更加困难。当你的公司只有几个月大的时候，它只需要是一个值得资助的有前景的实验，以看看结果如何。

paragraphs.original: The next time you raise money, the experiment has to have worked. You have to be on a trajectory that leads to going public. And while there are some ideas where the proof that the experiment worked might consist of e.g.
paragraphs.translated: 下次你筹集资金时，实验必须已经成功。你必须处于一个能够通往上市的轨道上。虽然有些想法的实验成功证明可能包括例如：

paragraphs.original: query response times, usually the proof is profitability. Usually phase 3 fundraising has to be type A fundraising.In practice there are two ways startups hose themselves between phases 2 and 3. Some are just too slow to become profitable.
paragraphs.translated: 查询响应时间，通常盈利能力就是证明。通常第三阶段的融资必须是A轮融资。实际上，初创公司在第二阶段和第三阶段之间有两种方式会拖累自己。有些公司变得盈利的速度太慢。

paragraphs.original: They raise enough money to last for two years. There doesn't seem any particular urgency to be profitable. So they don't make any effort to make money for a year. But by that time, not making money has become habitual.
paragraphs.translated: 他们筹集了足够维持两年的资金。似乎没有什么迫切需要盈利的压力。因此，他们在一年内都没有努力去赚钱。但到了那时，不赚钱已经成了习惯。

paragraphs.original: When they finally decide to try, they find they can't.The other way companies hose themselves is by letting their expenses grow too fast. Which almost always means hiring too many people. You usually shouldn't go out and hire 8 people as soon as you raise money at phase 2.
paragraphs.translated: 当他们最终决定尝试时，却发现无法做到。公司自我拖累的另一种方式是让开支增长过快，这几乎总是意味着雇佣了太多人。通常，在第二阶段筹集到资金后，你不应该立即出去雇佣8个人。

paragraphs.original: Usually you want to wait till you have growth (and thus usually revenues) to justify them. A lot of VCs will encourage you to hire aggressively. VCs generally tell you to spend too much, partly because as money people they err on the side of solving problems by spending money, and partly because they want you to sell them more of your company in subsequent rounds.
paragraphs.translated: 通常，你要等到公司有增长（因此通常也有收入）时，才能证明这些支出是合理的。很多风险投资家会鼓励你积极招聘。风险投资家通常会告诉你花更多的钱，部分原因是作为资金管理人，他们倾向于通过花钱来解决问题，部分原因是因为他们希望你在后续融资中向他们出售更多公司的股份。

paragraphs.original: Don't listen to them. Don't make things complicated.I realize it may seem odd to sum up this huge treatise by saying that my overall advice is not to make fundraising too complicated, but if you go back and look at this list you'll see it's basically a simple recipe with a lot of implications and edge cases.
paragraphs.translated: 不要听他们的。不要把事情复杂化。我意识到，用这样一句话来总结这篇长篇论述可能显得有些奇怪：我的总体建议是不要把融资过程搞得太复杂。但如果你回头看看这个清单，你会发现这基本上是一个简单的配方，只是有很多含义和特殊情况。

paragraphs.original: Avoid investors till you decide to raise money, and then when you do, talk to them all in parallel, prioritized by expected value, and accept offers greedily. That's fundraising in one sentence. Don't introduce complicated optimizations, and don't let investors introduce complications either.Fundraising is not what will make you successful.
paragraphs.translated: 在你决定要融资之前，避免接触投资者，一旦决定融资，就要同时与他们所有人沟通，按照预期价值的优先级进行，并贪婪地接受报价。这就是一句话概括的融资过程。不要引入复杂的优化策略，也不要让投资者引入复杂因素。融资不会让你成功。

paragraphs.original: It's just a means to an end. Your primary goal should be to get it over with and get back to what will make you successful — making things and talking to users — and the path I've described will for most startups be the surest way to that destination.Be good, take care of yourselves, and don't leave the path.
paragraphs.translated: 这只是一种达到目的的手段。你的主要目标应该是尽快完成它，然后回到那些能让你成功的事情上——制作产品和与用户交流——而我所描述的路径对大多数创业公司来说，将是到达目的地最稳妥的方式。好好表现，照顾好自己，不要偏离这条道路。

paragraphs.original: Notes[1] The worst explosions happen when unpromising-seeming startups encounter mediocre investors. Good investors don't lead startups on; their reputations are too valuable. And startups that seem promising can usually get enough money from good investors that they don't have to talk to mediocre ones.
paragraphs.translated: 注释[1] 最糟糕的爆炸发生在看似没有希望的初创公司遇到平庸的投资者时。优秀的投资者不会让初创公司抱有不切实际的期望；他们的声誉太过宝贵。而看似有潜力的初创公司通常能够从优秀的投资者那里获得足够的资金，从而不必与平庸的投资者打交道。

paragraphs.original: It is the unpromising-seeming startups that have to resort to raising money from mediocre investors. And it's particularly damaging when these investors flake, because unpromising-seeming startups are usually more desperate for money.(Not all unpromising-seeming startups do badly.
paragraphs.translated: 那些看似前景不被看好的初创公司不得不向实力平平的投资者募集资金。而当这些投资者中途退出时，对这些公司尤其具有破坏性，因为看似前景不被看好的初创公司通常更迫切需要资金。（并不是所有看似前景不被看好的初创公司都会表现不佳。

paragraphs.original: Some are merely ugly ducklings in the sense that they violate current startup fashions.)[2] One YC founder told me: I think in general we've done ok at fundraising, but I managed to screw up twice at the exact same thing — trying to focus on building the company and fundraising at the same time.
paragraphs.translated: 有些只是在违反当前创业潮流的意义上是丑小鸭。）[2] 一位YC创始人告诉我：我认为总体上我们在融资方面做得还不错，但我两次在同一问题上犯了错误——试图同时专注于建设和融资。

paragraphs.original: [3] There is one subtle danger you have to watch out for here, which I warn about later: beware of getting too high a valuation from an eager investor, lest that set an impossibly high target when raising additional money.[4] If they really need a meeting, then they're not ready to invest, regardless of what they say.
paragraphs.translated: [3] 这里有一个微妙的危险需要你留意，我稍后会警告：要当心过于热衷的投资者给出过高的估值，以免这在后续融资时设定一个无法达到的目标。[4] 如果他们真的需要安排会面，那么无论他们说什么，实际上都不准备投资。

paragraphs.original: They're still deciding, which means you're being asked to come in and convince them. Which is fundraising.[5] Associates at VC firms regularly cold email startups. Naive founders think "Wow, a VC is interested in us!" But an associate is not a VC.
paragraphs.translated: 他们还在做决定，这意味着你需要来尝试说服他们。这就是融资。风投公司的助理们经常主动给创业公司发邮件。天真的创始人会想：“哇，有风投对我们感兴趣！”但助理并不是风投。

paragraphs.original: They have no decision-making power. And while they may introduce startups they like to partners at their firm, the partners discriminate against deals that come to them this way. I don't know of a single VC investment that began with an associate cold-emailing a startup.
paragraphs.translated: 他们没有决策权。尽管他们可能会将自己喜欢的创业公司介绍给公司里的合伙人，但合伙人对通过这种方式来的交易持有偏见。我从未听说过有任何风险投资是由助理主动联系创业公司而开始的。

paragraphs.original: If you want to approach a specific firm, get an intro to a partner from someone they respect.It's ok to talk to an associate if you get an intro to a VC firm or they see you at a Demo Day and they begin by having an associate vet you.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你想接触某家特定的公司，可以通过他们尊敬的人引荐给一位合伙人。如果你得到一家风投公司的引荐，或者他们在演示日看到你后，开始由一位助理来考察你，这也是可以的。

paragraphs.original: That's not a promising lead and should therefore get low priority, but it's not as completely worthless as a cold email.Because the title "associate" has gotten a bad reputation, a few VC firms have started to give their associates the title "partner," which can make things very confusing.
paragraphs.translated: 这并不是一个很有希望的线索，因此应该给予较低的优先级，但它并不像冷邮件那样完全毫无价值。由于“助理”这一头衔名声不佳，一些风险投资公司开始将他们的助理称为“合伙人”，这可能会造成很大的混淆。

paragraphs.original: If you're a YC startup you can ask us who's who; otherwise you may have to do some research online. There may be a special title for actual partners. If someone speaks for the firm in the press or a blog on the firm's site, they're probably a real partner.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你是 YC 的初创公司，你可以向我们询问每个人的身份；否则，你可能需要在线上做一些调查。真正的合伙人可能会有一个特殊的头衔。如果某人在媒体或公司网站的博客中代表公司发言，他们很可能是一个真正的合伙人。

paragraphs.original: If they're on boards of directors they're probably a real partner.There are titles between "associate" and "partner," including "principal" and "venture partner." The meanings of these titles vary too much to generalize.[6] For similar reasons, avoid casual conversations with potential acquirers.
paragraphs.translated: 如果他们在董事会中，他们很可能是一位真正的合伙人。在“助理”和“合伙人”之间还有一些头衔，比如“主管”和“风险合伙人”。这些头衔的意义差异太大，难以一概而论。由于类似的原因，避免与潜在收购者进行随意的交谈。

paragraphs.original: They can lead to distractions even more dangerous than fundraising. Don't even take a meeting with a potential acquirer unless you want to sell your company right now.[7] Joshua Reeves specifically suggests asking each investor to intro you to two more investors.Don't ask investors who say no for introductions to other investors.
paragraphs.translated: 它们可能导致的分心甚至比筹款更加危险。除非你现在就想出售公司，否则不要与潜在的收购方会面。[7] Joshua Reeves 特别建议要求每位投资者为你介绍另外两位投资者。不要要求那些拒绝投资的人为你介绍其他投资者。

paragraphs.original: That will in many cases be an anti-recommendation.[8] This is not always as deliberate as its sounds. A lot of the delays and disconnects between founders and investors are induced by the customs of the venture business, which have evolved the way they have because they suit investors' interests.[9] One YC founder who read a draft of this essay wrote: This is the most important section.
paragraphs.translated: 这在很多情况下会是一个反建议。这并不总是像听起来那么刻意。创始人和投资者之间的许多延迟和脱节，都是由风险投资行业的惯例引起的，这些惯例之所以如此演变，是因为它们符合投资者的利益。一位阅读了本文草稿的YC创始人写道：这是最重要的一部分。

paragraphs.original: I think it might bear stating even more clearly. "Investors will deliberately affect more interest than they have to preserve optionality. If an investor seems very interested in you, they still probably won't invest.
paragraphs.translated: 我认为有必要更清楚地说明这一点。“投资者会故意表现出比实际更多的兴趣，以保留选择权。如果一个投资者对你表现出极大的兴趣，他们很可能最终还是不会投资。”

paragraphs.original: The solution for this is to assume the worst — that an investor is just feigning interest — until you get a definite commitment." [10] Though you should probably pack investor meetings as closely as you can, Jeff Byun mentions one reason not to: if you pack investor meetings too closely, you'll have less time for your pitch to evolve.Some founders deliberately schedule a handful of lame investors first, to get the bugs out of their pitch.[11] There is not an efficient market in this respect.
paragraphs.translated: 解决这个问题的方法是假设最坏的情况——投资者只是假装感兴趣——直到你得到明确的承诺。[10] 尽管你应该尽可能紧密地安排投资者会议，但杰夫·比恩提到一个不这么做的原因：如果你把投资者会议安排得太紧密，你就不会有足够的时间来完善你的演讲。一些创始人故意先安排几个不怎么样的投资者，以便在正式路演前发现并解决演讲中的问题。[11] 在这方面，并不存在一个有效的市场。

paragraphs.original: Some of the most useless investors are also the highest maintenance.[12] Incidentally, this paragraph is sales 101. If you want to see it in action, go talk to a car dealer.[13] I know one very smooth founder who used to end investor meetings with "So, can I count you in?" delivered as if it were "Can you pass the salt?" Unless you're very smooth (if you're not sure...), do not do this yourself.
paragraphs.translated: 一些最无用的投资者往往也是最需要照顾的。顺便说一句，这一段是销售101。如果你想看到实际效果，去和一个汽车销售谈谈。我认识一个非常圆滑的创始人，他以前在投资者会议结束时会说：“所以，我能把你算进去吗？”这句话说得好像在问“你能递一下盐吗？”除非你非常圆滑（如果你不确定……），否则不要这样做。

paragraphs.original: There is nothing more unconvincing, for an investor, than a nerdy founder trying to deliver the lines meant for a smooth one.Investors are fine with funding nerds. So if you're a nerd, just try to be a good nerd, rather than doing a bad imitation of a smooth salesman.[14] Ian Hogarth suggests a good way to tell how serious potential investors are: the resources they expend on you after the first meeting.
paragraphs.translated: 对于投资者来说，没有什么比一个书生气的创始人试图像一个圆滑的销售人员那样说话更不令人信服的了。投资者并不介意资助书生气的人。所以，如果你是一个书生气的人，就努力做一个优秀的书生气的人，而不是做一个糟糕的圆滑销售人员的模仿者。[14] Ian Hogarth 建议，判断潜在投资者是否认真的一个好方法是：他们在第一次会面后为你投入的资源。

paragraphs.original: An investor who's seriously interested will already be working to help you even before they've committed.[15] In principle you might have to think about so-called "signalling risk." If a prestigious VC makes a small seed investment in you, what if they don't want to invest the next time you raise money?
paragraphs.translated: 一个真正感兴趣的投资者甚至在正式承诺之前就会开始帮助你。原则上，你可能需要考虑所谓的“信号风险”。如果一位声誉卓著的风险投资家在你这里进行了小额种子投资，那么如果他们下次你筹集资金时不愿意再投资，该怎么办？

paragraphs.original: Other investors might assume that the VC knows you well, since they're an existing investor, and if they don't want to invest in your next round, that must mean you suck. The reason I say "in principle" is that in practice signalling hasn't been much of a problem so far.
paragraphs.translated: 其他投资者可能会认为，由于该风险投资已经是你的现有投资者，他们对你很了解，如果他们不愿意参与你下一轮的融资，那一定意味着你不行。我之所以说“原则上”是因为实际上到目前为止，信号效应还没有成为太大的问题。

paragraphs.original: It rarely arises, and in the few cases where it does, the startup in question usually is doing badly and is doomed anyway.If you have the luxury of choosing among seed investors, you can play it safe by excluding VC firms.
paragraphs.translated: 这种情况很少发生，即便发生，相关的初创企业通常已经表现不佳，注定要失败。如果你有选择种子轮投资者的余地，可以通过排除风投公司来降低风险。

paragraphs.original: But it isn't critical to.[16] Sometimes a competitor will deliberately threaten you with a lawsuit just as you start fundraising, because they know you'll have to disclose the threat to potential investors and they hope this will make it harder for you to raise money.
paragraphs.translated: 但这并不是关键所在。有时，竞争对手会在你开始筹集资金时故意威胁要起诉你，因为他们知道你必须向潜在投资者披露这一威胁，他们希望这会使你更难筹集资金。

paragraphs.original: If this happens it will probably frighten you more than investors. Experienced investors know about this trick, and know the actual lawsuits rarely happen. So if you're attacked in this way, be forthright with investors.
paragraphs.translated: 如果发生这种情况，它可能会吓到你多于投资者。经验丰富的投资者了解这种伎俩，并知道实际诉讼很少发生。因此，如果你以这种方式受到攻击，对投资者要坦诚。

paragraphs.original: They'll be more alarmed if you seem evasive than if you tell them everything.[17] A related trick is to claim that they'll only invest contingently on other investors doing so because otherwise you'd be "undercapitalized." This is almost always bullshit.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你表现得闪烁其词，他们反而会更加警惕，还不如把一切都告诉他们。[17] 一个相关的技巧是声称只有在其他投资者也参与的情况下他们才会投资，因为否则你会“资本不足”。这几乎总是胡说八道。

paragraphs.original: They can't estimate your minimum capital needs that precisely.[18] You won't hire all those 20 people at once, and you'll probably have some revenues before 18 months are out. But those too are acceptable or at least accepted additions to the margin for error.[19] Type A fundraising is so much better that it might even be worth doing something different if it gets you there sooner.
paragraphs.translated: 他们无法精确估算你的最低资本需求。你不会一次性雇用所有20个人，而且在18个月内你可能会有一些收入。但这些也是可以接受的，或者至少是被接受的误差范围内的补充。A类融资如此之好，以至于如果能让你更快到达那里，甚至值得为此做一些不同的事情。

paragraphs.original: One YC founder told me that if he were a first-time founder again he'd "leave ideas that are up-front capital intensive to founders with established reputations."[20] I don't know whether this happens because they're innumerate, or because they believe they have zero ability to predict startup outcomes (in which case this behavior at least wouldn't be irrational).
paragraphs.translated: 一位YC创始人告诉我，如果他再次成为首次创业者，他会“将那些一开始就需要大量资金的项目留给那些声誉已经建立的创始人。”我不清楚这是否是因为他们不懂数学，还是因为他们认为自己完全无法预测创业结果（如果是后者，那么这种行为至少不会是非理性的）。

paragraphs.original: In either case the implications are similar.[21] If you're a YC startup and you have an investor who for some reason insists that you decide the price, any YC partner can estimate a market price for you.[22] You should respond in kind when investors behave upstandingly too.
paragraphs.translated: 在这两种情况下，影响是相似的。如果你是一家 YC 初创公司，而某个投资者出于某种原因坚持要你来定价，任何 YC 合伙人都可以为你估算一个市场价格。当投资者表现出高尚的行为时，你也应该以同样的方式回应。

paragraphs.original: When an investor makes you a clean offer with no deadline, you have a moral obligation to respond promptly.[23] Tell the investors talking to you about an A round about the smaller investments you raise as you raise them.
paragraphs.translated: 当投资者向您提出一个没有截止日期的明确报价时，您有道德上的义务及时回应。[23] 在进行A轮融资时，每当您筹集到小额投资，都应告知正在与您交谈的投资者。

paragraphs.original: You owe them such updates on your cap table, and this is also a good way to pressure them to act. They won't like you raising other money and may pressure you to stop, but they can't legitimately ask you to commit to them till they also commit to you.
paragraphs.translated: 你需要向他们提供你资本表的更新，这同时也是促使他们采取行动的好方法。他们可能不喜欢你筹集其他资金，并可能向你施压要求你停止，但他们不能正当地要求你向他们承诺，除非他们也向你做出承诺。

paragraphs.original: If they want you to stop raising money, the way to do it is to give you a series A termsheet with a no-shop clause.You can relent a little if the potential series A investor has a great reputation and they're clearly working fast to get you a termsheet, particularly if a third party like YC is involved to ensure there are no misunderstandings.
paragraphs.translated: 如果他们希望你停止融资，方法是给你一份包含“不得进行其他谈判”条款的A轮融资条款书。如果潜在的A轮投资者声誉卓著，并且他们显然正在迅速推进条款书的签署，特别是如果有YC这样的第三方介入以确保没有误解的情况下，你可以稍微让步。

paragraphs.original: But be careful.[24] The company is Weebly, which made it to profitability on a seed investment of $650k. They did try to raise a series A in the fall of 2008 but (no doubt partly because it was the fall of 2008) the terms they were offered were so bad that they decided to skip raising an A round.[25] Another advantage of having one founder take fundraising meetings is that you never have to negotiate in real time, which is something inexperienced founders should avoid.
paragraphs.translated: 但要小心。这家公司是Weebly，他们凭借65万美元的种子投资实现了盈利。他们确实尝试在2008年秋季进行A轮融资，但由于当时正值2008年秋季（无疑部分原因也在于此），他们得到的融资条件非常糟糕，因此决定放弃A轮融资。另一位创始人参加融资会议的一个优势是，你不必实时进行谈判，这是缺乏经验的创始人应该避免的情况。

paragraphs.original: One YC founder told me: Investors are professional negotiators and can negotiate on the spot very easily. If only one founder is in the room, you can say "I need to circle back with my co-founder" before making any commitments.
paragraphs.translated: 一位YC创始人告诉我：投资者是专业的谈判者，能够非常轻松地当场进行谈判。如果只有你一位创始人在场，你可以说“我需要与我的联合创始人商讨后再做决定”。

paragraphs.original: I used to do this all the time. [26] You'll be lucky if fundraising feels pleasant enough to become addictive. More often you have to worry about the other extreme — becoming demoralized when investors reject you.
paragraphs.translated: 我过去经常这样做。[26] 如果你有幸觉得筹集资金足够愉快而变得上瘾，那你是幸运的。更常见的情况是你必须担心另一个极端——当投资者拒绝你时感到士气低落。

paragraphs.original: As one (very successful) YC founder wrote after reading a draft of this: It's hard to mentally deal with the sheer scale of rejection in fundraising and if you are not in the right mindset you will fail.
paragraphs.translated: 正如一位（非常成功的）YC创始人在阅读了本文草稿后所写：在融资过程中，要心理上应对大量的拒绝是很难的，如果你的心态不正确，你就会失败。

paragraphs.original: Users may love you but these supposedly smart investors may not understand you at all. At this point for me, rejection still rankles but I've come to accept that investors are just not super thoughtful for the most part and you need to play the game according to certain somewhat depressing rules (many of which you are listing) in order to win.
paragraphs.translated: 用户可能喜欢你，但这些所谓的精明投资者可能根本不懂你。对我来说，被拒仍然让我感到刺痛，但我已经接受了一个事实，即投资者大多并不特别明智，你需要按照某些令人沮丧的规则（你列出的许多规则）来玩游戏，才能获胜。
